descriptions.description: High-quality software with more features enhances the project's public perception and credibility.
A larger user base provides more testimonials and visibility, which bolsters the project's reputation.
More core developers increase the available review capacity, which can reduce the delay in reviewing pull requests.
A shorter review delay means contributors receive feedback faster, increasing the rate of feedback.
A larger backlog of pull requests under review increases the total volume of feedback being generated.
A larger base of implicit knowledge provides more material for experienced members to share through mentorship.
More core developers increase the capacity for providing mentorship and transferring implicit knowledge.
Timely and helpful feedback encourages newcomers to stay and formally join as new contributors.
Constructive feedback helps experienced contributors improve their skills and solidify their role.
Effective feedback helps experienced contributors develop the expertise required to become core developers.
New contributors, as they learn, begin to provide feedback on other pull requests.
Experienced contributors provide a significant portion of the code review and feedback.
The process of giving feedback is part of the review workflow, keeping pull requests in the 'under review' state.
Well-documented explicit knowledge makes it easier to create guides and documentation for newcomers.
Feedback from pull requests often contains solutions and insights that are archived in the knowledge base.
Resolved issues provide documented solutions and lessons learned that enrich the searchable knowledge base.
A comprehensive knowledge base serves as a primary resource that constitutes the project's explicit knowledge.
Community discussions generate questions, answers, and decisions that are valuable additions to the knowledge base.
A strong project reputation attracts more potential contributors, increasing their joining rate.
A good reputation draws in new users, thereby increasing the total user base.
Open issues generate user reports and discussions, which are a primary source of community feedback.
Community feedback often identifies new problems or clarifies existing ones, leading to more open issues.
A healthy, collaborative community is a positive signal that enhances the project's overall reputation.
A positive project reputation makes it more attractive for new contributors to join.
Good documentation lowers the barrier to entry, making it easier for newcomers to join the project.
More time spent by maintainers on issues directly increases the rate at which issues are resolved.
The issue resolution flow adds to the stock of closed issues.
The flow of newly created issues adds to the stock of open issues.
Resolving issues removes them from the open issues stock.
A larger and more complex codebase provides more surface area for bugs and feature requests, increasing issue creation.
Positive project activities and outcomes accumulate over time to build the project's reputation.
Negative events or stagnation cause the project's reputation to decline over time.
When explicit knowledge is internalized and becomes tacit, it is no longer tracked as explicit.
The process of codifying knowledge adds new documentation and guides to the explicit knowledge stock.
New users adopting the software increase the total user base.
Users leaving the project reduce the total user base.
Merging a pull request removes it from the 'under review' stock.
Rejecting a pull request removes it from the 'under review' stock.
Initiating the review process for a new pull request adds it to the 'under review' stock.
Merging pull requests integrates new code into the main source code stock.
Accessible documentation helps contributors learn faster, accelerating their skill development.
Direct mentorship accelerates learning and skill acquisition for contributors.
Active community engagement generates discussions and solutions that are added to the knowledge base.
Open issues often represent bugs or desired features that motivate contributors to submit pull requests.
The inflow of new pull requests adds to the stock of new pull requests awaiting initial review.
When a review starts, a pull request moves from 'new' to 'under review', reducing the new stock.
Developers leaving the project reduce the number of core developers.
Promoting experienced contributors to core roles increases the core developer stock.
Effective mentorship prepares and qualifies experienced contributors for promotion to core roles.
When developers leave, their unique tacit knowledge is lost from the project.
Promoting an experienced contributor to a core developer moves them out of the experienced contributor stock.
As contributors develop skills, they graduate from being new to experienced contributors.
The inflow of new people joining the project adds to the stock of new contributors.
As new contributors gain skills, they move out of the 'new' stock into the 'experienced' stock.
The departure of experienced developers erodes the project's collective tacit knowledge.
When contributors internalize explicit knowledge, it becomes part of the project's implicit knowledge.
The act of codifying implicit knowledge into explicit form reduces the stock of purely implicit knowledge.
Negative interactions and burnout degrade the collaborative spirit and well-being of the community.
Positive interactions and reliable collaboration build trust and strengthen community health.
